elements.name: welcome_preamble
elements.html:
Welcome to the 2019-20 {course} post-course survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about our curriculum and your teaching experience.

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share anonymous, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your anonymized responses will be used by Code.org, our Regional Partners, and our facilitators for program improvement.

This survey should take less than 15 minutes to complete.

At the end you will be offered a $10 Amazon gift card for your time (supplies limited).

Your honesty and candor are appreciated and help us improve.

elements.name: teaching_context_header
elements.html:
Teaching Context

This survey is about teaching with Code.org materials and resources during the 2019-20 school year.

We recognize the unique nature of teaching this year with the COVID-19 outbreak affecting most, if not all, schools. In this survey we address the impacts that COVID-19 had on your classroom, as well as what it was like teaching the course under "normal" circumstances.

Let's get started!

elements.name: grade_levels_taught
elements.title: At what grade levels did you teach {course} this year? [select all that apply]

elements.name: csf_which_course
elements.title: Which courses of CS Fundamentals did you teach? Please check any courses you taught all or most of with students.

elements.name: csf_teacher_role
elements.title: What type of role applies best to you?

elements.name: csd_which_units
elements.title: Which units of CS Discoveries did you teach? Please check any units you taught all or most of.

elements.name: csp_which_units
elements.title: Which units of CS Principles did you teach? Please check any units you taught all or most of.

elements.name: csp_taught_as_ap
elements.title: This year I taught CS Principles as...

elements.name: other_ap_courses_taught
elements.title: What other AP courses did you teach this school year (2019-20), if any?

elements.name: course_required
elements.title: At your school, is {course} a required or elective course?

choices.text: Required (or part of a rotation that all students do at some point)
Integrated into other subjects or school activities.

elements.name: years_taught_codeorg
elements.title: How many years have you taught using the Code.org {course} curriculum?

elements.name: post_covid_preamble
elements.html:
Impacts of COVID-19 on your classroom - Teaching Remotely

The COVID-19 pandemic changed the way almost all schools in the US operated around mid-March, 2020. Most schools switched completely, or in part, to remote or virtual learning environments.

We’d like you to reflect on the impacts of COVID-19 pandemic on your classroom. 

This section asks you about teaching Code.org remotely. We assume that most teachers did some or all of their teaching remotely at some point after March, 2020.  Please answer the items below thinking about any remote teaching you did.

elements.name: use_of_cdo_when_remote
elements.title: Which of the following most closely describes how you taught your students with Code.org materials once you switched to remote learning.

choices.text: I mostly or completely stopped teaching {course}.
I kept teaching computer science but switched to using materials from other web sites or programs.
I continued to use Code.org resources, but NOT those that were part of the {course} course I was teaching originally.
I continued to teach {course} but with major modifications to support remote learning.
I continued to teach {course} more or less the same as I was before.
I did not switch to remote learning.

elements.name: pct_course_not_taught
elements.title: Considering the entire 2019-20 school year, by your estimation, what % of {course} were you NOT able to teach due the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on your classroom?

elements.name: video_conf_tool_remote
elements.title: When teaching remotely, what was the primary video conferencing technology you used?

choices.text: None - I did not host class sessions via video conference

elements.name: days_per_week_video_conf_remote
elements.title: When teaching remotely, approximately how many MINUTES PER WEEK did you teach via a class conference call?

elements.name: lms_tool_remote
elements.title: What is the primary Learning Management System (LMS) you make use of?  (If you, your school or district uses multiple LMS's please choose the one you like the most)

choices.text: None - I don't really use an LMS

elements.name: third_party_integration_FR
elements.title: Are there any third party tools you use in your classroom that you wish were better integrated with Code.org (e.g., LMS, collaboration apps, communication apps, etc.)? If so, which tools and how would you want to use them with Code.org?

elements.name: curriculum_impressions_remote
elements.title: What are your overall impressions teaching with the Code.org {course} curriculum, once you switched to remote learning?

rows.text: I loved teaching with the curriculum.
This curriculum was effective for my students.
The teaching strategies recommended in the curriculum and lesson plans were clear to me.
The tools and technologies that are part of the curriculum make sense and are easy to use.

elements.name: challenges_remote
elements.title: Please characterize the challenges you faced teaching your students with Code.org remotely.

rows.text: Internet and/or device access for me or my students
Providing support and assistance while students work
Tracking student progress on assigned materials
Providing feedback on work students have done
Assigning new work
Finding materials that students can work on independently
Getting students their login information, or getting students signed in to the website
Finding materials to work on that don't require internet and device access
Communicating with my students while they are at home
Providing instruction on new concepts to my students
Finding ways for students to collaborate
Lack of integration with my school’s Learning Management System (LMS)

elements.name: one_challenge_FR_remote
elements.title: For one of the items you identified as a challenge (or for a different challenge not listed), please describe any ideas you have for how Code.org might address it.

elements.name: cdo_supports_used
elements.title: Code.org created some supports for at home teachers and students this past spring. Did you use any of these supports?

columns.text: I tried this, but it wasn't helpful/I didn't like it
I tried this and it was helpful/I liked it

rows.text: Code Break weekly coding lessons
Parent letter with Code.org sign in information
Guide for teaching {course} during school closures
Create PT resources
Project ideas

elements.name: cdo_strategies_remote
elements.title: When teaching {course} remotely, how often did YOU explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Ask students to write code with another student.
Ask a student to give feedback on a classmate’s work.
Ask a student to share their ideas with classmates in small group or large group discussion.
Remind students that failure is a normal and natural part of the problem solving process.
Gave students the opportunity to write their thoughts down in a journal or on paper.

elements.name: facilitation_student_interest_remote
elements.title: When teaching {course} remotely, how often did YOU explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Connected lessons or activities to students' lives (e.g., by asking about past experiences, or applying content to students' daily lives).
Asked students to consider relationships between lesson content and real world problems (actual events or situations within or outside of school).

elements.name: facilitation_cog_demand_remote
elements.title: When teaching {course} remotely, how often did you explicitly ASK STUDENTS to do the following?

rows.text: Consider alternative approaches to their work.
Explain the logic and reasoning supporting their solutions.
Explain why they agree or disagree with the work of other students.

elements.name: drop_off_FR_remote
elements.title: Last, if there is anything else you'd like us to know about the impact COVID-19 had on your {course} classroom, please let us know here.

elements.name: pre_covid_preamble
elements.html:
Your classroom BEFORE remote learning

If you can, please take a moment (and a deep breath) and think back to your classroom prior to the time your school switched to remote learning.  We'll refer to this as your 'normal' classroom -- what your classroom environment was like when you held in-person class sessions.

PLEASE NOTE: some of the same questions we asked in the previous section are repeated intentionally.

elements.name: mins_per_week_normal
elements.title: For a typical section of {course} that you teach, how many MINUTES PER WEEK (on average) does that section meet under normal circumstances?

elements.name: num_weeks_normal
elements.title: For a typical section of {course} that you teach, approximately how many WEEKS does the class run under normal circumstances?

elements.name: curriculum_impressions_normal
elements.title: What are your overall impressions teaching with the Code.org {course} curriculum this year under normal conditions?

rows.text: I loved teaching with the curriculum.
This curriculum was effective for my students.
The teaching strategies recommended in the curriculum and lesson plans were clear to me.
The tools and technologies that are part of the curriculum made sense and were easy to use.

elements.name: challenges_normal
elements.title: Please characterize the challenges you faced with teaching your students {course} in your normal classroom.

rows.text: Internet and/or device access for me or my students
Providing support and assistance while students work
Tracking student progress on assigned materials
Providing feedback on work students have done
Assigning new work
Finding materials that students can work on independently
Getting students their login information, or getting students signed in to the site
Finding materials to work on that don't require internet and device access
Communicating with my students while they are at home
Providing instruction on new concepts to my students
Finding ways for students to collaborate
Lack of integration with my school’s technology or LMS (Learning Management System)

elements.name: one_challenge_FR_normal
elements.title: For one of the items you identified as a challenge, please describe any ideas you have for how Code.org might address it.

rows.text: Ask students to write code with another student.

Ask a student to share their ideas with classmates in small group or large group discussion.
Remind students that failure is a normal and natural part of the problem solving process.
Gave students the opportunity to write their thoughts down in a journal or on paper.

elements.name: facilitation_of_student_interest_normal
elements.title: When teaching {course} under normal circumstances how often did YOU explicitly do the following?

rows.text: Connected lessons or activities to students' lives (e.g., by asking about past experiences, or applying content to students' daily lives).
Asked students to consider relationships between lesson content and real world problems (meaning actual events or situations within or outside of school).

elements.name: facilitation_of_cog_demand_normal
elements.title: When teaching {course} under normal circumstances how often did you ASK STUDENTS explicitly to do the following?

rows.text: Consider alternative approaches to their work.
Explain the logic and reasoning supporting their solutions.
Explain why they agree or disagree with the work of other students.

elements.name: next_year_concerns
elements.title: In thinking about teaching {course} again next year, I am concerned about…

rows.text: Systemic supports (district, school, principal, community, families, etc.).
The amount of time needed to cover all the material.
My class being fully enrolled (or recruiting students into the class)
Computer science being offered by my school if students are at home
Teaching Code.org materials (specifically) if students are at home
Teaching computer science (in general) if students are at home
Teaching (in general) if students are at home

elements.name: next_year_plan_to_open
elements.title: To the best of your knowledge which best describes your school's plans for opening next school year.
elements.description: If you are unsure or it's still unknown, choose the option that seems most reasonable or likely to you.

elements.name: pct_inperson_v_remote
elements.title: For a hybrid situation, what % of class hours do you anticipate having for in-person learning?
elements.description: If no official announcements have been made at your school yet, please choose the option that seems most reasonable or likely to you.

elements.name: pct_sync_v_async
elements.title: For fully remote, what % of class hours do anticipate having synchronously (i.e. class meets at a specific time via video conference)?
elements.description: If no official announcements have been made at your school yet, please choose the option that seems most reasonable or likely to you.

elements.name: connectedness_to_cs_ed_community
elements.title: What are your perceptions about your connectedness to the broader CS Education community?

rows.text: I feel connected to a community of CS teachers.
When I need help teaching CS, I have someone to turn to.
I know CS teacher leaders and role models in my community.
I feel like I'm part of a broad CS education movement.

elements.name: community_values_cs
elements.title: What are your perceptions about how your school and community values and supports computer science?

rows.text: There is student demand for more computer science courses in my school.
My school leaders tell others in our school about the benefits of offering computer science.
Counselors at my school communicate the benefits of computer science to all students.
Families here think offering computer science is important.
I have strong administrative support for teaching CS.
My school administration provides me with high quality feedback and evaluation of my CS instruction.

elements.name: gift_card_conf_header
elements.html:
Amazon Gift Card Confirmation

Please accept a small token of appreciation in the form of an Amazon gift card, while supplies last.*

*First 250 respondents will receive gift card. Please allow 1-2 weeks to receive code.

elements.name: permission
